name: Understanding fractions as multiples of a unit fraction

skills.name: Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction Ã— Integer
Represent multiplication of unit fractions visually

explanations.A: You have added the 1 & 4 but we need to multiply them!
explanations.B: You have multiplied the numerator and denominator, but we only multiply the numerator by 4...
explanations.C: You have multiplied the denominator by 4 but we need to multiply the numerator instead...

explanations.A: 7 lots of 1/4 is 7/4. We multiply the numerator by 7 to get the answer.
explanations.B: You have multiplied the denominator by 7 but we need to multiply the numerator instead...
explanations.C: You have multiplied both the numerator and denominator, but we only multiply the numerator by 7...
explanations.D: You have added the 1 & 7 but we need to multiply them!

explanations.A: Each piece represents 1/4 as it is a whole split into 4 parts with one part shaded, we have 5 pieces so the model represents 1/4 x 5
explanations.B: Look at the shading, each piece isn't worth 4/4, what is it worth?
explanations.C: Each piece is 1 whole split into 4 parts with one part shaded, how do we represent this as a fraction? Then there are 5 pieces so what do we need to multiply by?
explanations.D: Each piece is 1 whole split into 4 parts with one part shaded, how do we represent this as a fraction? Then there are 5 pieces so what do we need to multiply by?

explanations.A: Look at the shading, each piece isn't worth 8/8, what is it worth?
explanations.B: Each piece represents 1/8 as it is a whole split into 8 parts with one part shaded, we have 3 pieces so the model represents 1/8 x 3
explanations.C: Each piece is 1 whole split into 8 parts with one part shaded, how do we represent this as a fraction? Then there are 3 pieces so what do we need to multiply by?
explanations.D: Each piece is 1 whole split into 8 parts with one part shaded, how do we represent this as a fraction? Then there are 3 pieces so what do we need to multiply by?

explanations.A: This model correctly has 2 wholes but only 1/3 is shaded, we need the model that has 2 wholes and 2 pieces of 1/3 shaded in...
explanations.B: This model represents 2 x 1/3 as there are two wholes, each one is split into 3 equal parts with 1 part shaded
explanations.C: This model represents 1 x 1/3. We need a model with 2 wholes and 2 pieces of 1/3 shaded in...
explanations.D: This model represents 2 x 3/3. We are looking for the model that represents 2 x 1/3...

explanations.A: This model represents 3 x 5/5. We are looking for the model that represents 3 x 1/5...
explanations.B: This model represents 1 x 1/5. We need a model with 3 wholes and 3 pieces of 1/5 shaded in...
explanations.C: This model correctly has 3 wholes but only 1/5 is shaded, we need the model that has 3 wholes and 3 pieces of 1/5 shaded in...
explanations.D: This model represents 3 x 1/5 as there are three wholes, each one is split into 5 equal parts with 1 part shaded

explanations.A: 0 is not what each jump is worth, look at the number line again to work out the value of each jump...
explanations.B: I think you have counted the number of lines, rather than the number of jumps...
explanations.C: Each jump is worth 1/5, we have 4 jumps and we end on 4/5 putting this together gives the calculation 1/5 x 4 = 4/5
explanations.D: To work out the calculation: find the value of each jump, how many jumps there are and what number the jumps end on...

explanations.A: Each jump is worth 1/7, we have 6 jumps and we end on 6/7 putting this together gives the calculation 1/7 x 6 = 6/7
explanations.B: To work out the calculation: find the value of each jump, how many jumps there are and what number the jumps end on...
explanations.C: I think you have counted the number of lines, rather than the number of jumps...
explanations.D: 0 is not what each jump is worth, look at the number line again to work out the value of each jump...

explanations.A: 12/6 means 12 pieces of 1/6 so the missing number is 12
explanations.B: 12/6 does equal 2 but we are working out how many 1/6 there are in 12/6...
explanations.C: To find the missing value, you need to think about what multiplied by 1/6 gives 12/6. If you have 1 of something and then 12 of something, what have you multiplied it by?
explanations.D: 11/6 + 1/6 = 12/6 but we are looking for what multiplied by 1/6 gives 12/6...

explanations.A: 14/3 + 1/3 = 15/3 but we are looking for what multiplied by 1/3 gives 15/3...
explanations.B: To find the missing value, you need to think about what multiplied by 1/3 gives 15/3. If you have 1 of something and then 15 of something, what have you multiplied it by?
explanations.C: 15/3 means 15 pieces of 1/3 so the missing number is 15
explanations.D: 15/3 does equal 5 but we are working out how many 1/3 there are in 15/3...
